bestBHT.bht: Judas, frequently using the title Rabbi in his addresses to Jesus, showed familiarity in their relationship. However, it is important to note that this does not exclude Judas from acknowledging Jesus as Lord. The act of Judas kissing Jesus exemplified his deep affection and high regard for Him. This display of betrayal carries greater weight when considering the significant bond that existed between Judas and Jesus.

Henry Alford: Rabbi appears to have been the usual form in which Judas addressed our Lord.
We must not conclude from this with Bengel, that he never seems to have called Him Lord.
John Gill: He goeth straightway to him; alone; as if he had nothing to do with the company behind, and as if he was his friend, and concerned for his safety.
Expressing great affection for him, and respect to him, by repeating this word.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Mark 14:45, it is noted that Judas, in addressing Jesus, commonly referred to Him as Rabbi. This does not mean that Judas never called Him Lord, but it is important to recognize the significance of this title. The act of Judas kissing Jesus should also be noted, as it can be seen as an expression of affection and respect. This moment reflects the deep bond that Judas had with Jesus, despite his betrayal.

In this passage, it is evident that Judas often addressed Jesus as Rabbi, showcasing their familiar relationship. However, it is important to note that this does not imply that Judas never acknowledged Jesus as Lord. By kissing Jesus, Judas displayed a strong affection and deep respect towards Him, emphasizing the significant bond they shared. This act of betrayal becomes all the more poignant when considering the closeness that once existed between Judas and Jesus.

Judas, in his interactions with Jesus, frequently used the title Rabbi, signifying the familiarity of their relationship. It should be noted, however, that this does not negate the fact that Judas did refer to Jesus as Lord at certain times. The significance of Judas kissing Jesus cannot be overlooked. Through this act, Judas expressed both deep affection and profound respect, highlighting their close bond. This act of betrayal becomes even more impactful when considering the prior intimacy between Judas and Jesus.

In Mark 14:45, Judas commonly addressed Jesus as Rabbi, while still acknowledging Him as Lord at times. Judas's act of kissing Jesus demonstrated both deep affection and profound respect. This emotional act of betrayal is poignant, given the close bond between Judas and Jesus.

Judas, frequently using the title Rabbi in his addresses to Jesus, showed familiarity in their relationship. However, it is important to note that this does not exclude Judas from acknowledging Jesus as Lord. The act of Judas kissing Jesus exemplified his deep affection and high regard for Him. This display of betrayal carries greater weight when considering the significant bond that existed between Judas and Jesus.
